item.title: Henri Bergius
item.description:
Henri Bergius

Hacker and an occasional adventurer. Author of Create.js and NoFlo. Decoupling software, one piece at a time.

item.title: Futures of text
item.description:
Futures of text

When the weather is bad I take a bus to work. I'm forever grateful to the person at the bus stop who informed me that you can text New York's MTA service to find out exactly where the bus is and when it's going to arrive.

item.title: How we got gripped by the hand-held device
item.description:
How we got gripped by the hand-held device

For centuries, the powerful would never hold anything useful for themselves. How did devices become universal luxuries?

item.title: Theoretical Motivations for Deep Learning
item.description:
Theoretical Motivations for Deep Learning

This post is based on the lecture "Deep Learning: Theoretical Motivations" given by Dr. Yoshua Bengio at Deep Learning Summer School, Montreal 2015. I highly recommend the lecture for a deeper understanding of the topic. Deep learning is a branch of machine learning algorithms based on learning multiple levels of representation.

item.title: Safe Harbour and how to protect your business and customer data
item.description:
Safe Harbour and how to protect your business and customer data

A simple explanation of Safe Harbour, what it means to you or your business and what you could do to take that next step into protecting that data. Safe Harbour was a policy agreement between the United States Department of Commerce and the European Commission to regulate how US companies manage the personal data of European citizens.

item.title: Nexus 6P Review: This Is The Android Device That You've Been Waiting For
item.description:
Nexus 6P Review: This Is The Android Device That You've Been Waiting For

Sundar Pichai made his first public presentation as Google's CEO last month and showed off a slew of new hardware devices. One of the two phones announced was the Nexus 6P by Huawei. For the flagship Nexus phones is bigger necessarily better? Let's find out. New phones are exciting.

item.title: bttn
item.description:
bttn

bttn is just what the name suggests: a connected push button that can trigger actions. Use it to send a message, control your smart appliances or turn music on/off. The bttn has built-in internet connectivity and needs no smartphones or apps to pair with.

item.title: Jon Nordby - Death to Black Boxes
item.description:
Jon Nordby - Death to Black Boxes

Session: Democratizing Knowledge 2014 Open Hardware Summit

item.title: The Most Mysterious Star in Our Galaxy
item.description:
The Most Mysterious Star in Our Galaxy

Astronomers have spotted a strange mess of objects whirling around a distant star. Scientists who search for extraterrestrial civilizations are scrambling to get a closer look.

item.title: From Gongkai to Open Source
item.description:
From Gongkai to Open Source

About a year and a half ago, I wrote about a $12 "Gongkai" cell phone that I stumbled across in the markets of Shenzhen, China. My most striking impression was that Chinese entrepreneurs had relatively unfettered access to cutting-edge technology, enabling start-ups to innovate while bootstrapping.
